headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: After Election Day: What`s Next? Astronauts Emerge From Space Capsule After Six-Month Mission; UWC Red Cross Nordic. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, CNN projects Republicans will win control of the Senate, delivering the party`s first majority in the chamber since 2021.The Senate will then have its own election for a Republican leader set to happen next week. At the time this show was written, control of the House of Representatives has yet to be called. Republicans are defending a narrow majority there and it could take a week or more before those races are determined. The work of an election doesn`t stop now that Donald Trump is the projected winner of the contest. Our Phil Mattingly walks us through what happens after every ballot is cast and shows us how we get to inauguration day. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN CHIEF DOMESTIC CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: So what happens after an election? Turns out, a lot. Officials count the ballots in the states. Andwhile news agencies like CNN may project a winner --

utterances.speaker: WOLF BLITZER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: -- of the presidential race --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- doesn`t mean it`s over, especially if there are legal challenges, it could actually take weeks. Now, the vote must be certifiedby December 11th, and that`s where the Electoral College comes into play. See, you might remember, you actually vote for electors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Has the tally been completed?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, Lieutenant Governor.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And on December 17th, those electors meet, cast their votes, and then send them off to Washington. And if you`re wondering why electorsdon`t go rogue, well, it turns out in most states there are laws binding them to the decision made by their voters. They can`t actually go their own way. And then in January, just a few days after a new Congress is sworn in, those votes are read.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: 232 votes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And then they are counted before the new House and Senate chambers.JOE BIDEN, (D) U.S. PRESIDENT:  Dissolved.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And after all of that, on January 20th of 2025, the new president and vice president are sworn in to begin their four-year term inoffice. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: Ten-second trivia.In addition to the International Space Station, the United States, Russia, and what other country have each independently launched and operated their own space stations? Canada, India, Japan, or China? Your answer here is China, which constructed the Tiangong Space Station, a crewed space station operated by the China Manned Space Agency. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This is the moment China`s Shenzhou-18 capsule touched down on Earth on November 4th.LI CONG, SHENZHOU-18 CREW MEMBER (through translation):  Although we have successfully completed this Shenzhou-18 mission, the exploration of space never ends. LI GUANGSU, SHENZHOU-18 CREW MEMBER (through translation):  Space is vast, magical and beautiful. We all really enjoy the unique experience of weightlessness.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The three-person crew spent six months at China`s space station. There, they ran dozens of experiments, including monitoringa tank of zebrafish in a closed mini-ecosystem, according to China`s state broadcaster CCTV. The astronauts also brought back more than 50 samples. Some of these could be used to study the habitability of space environments, reports China`s Xinhua news agency. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: Imagine a school where one of your classrooms is the second longest coastline in the world. Well, this unique school, UWC Red CrossNordic, is located in one of Norway`s many fjords, or inlets, and is home to hundreds of students from over 80 countries. The school`s humanitarian and environmental focus strives to unite people of all cultures for peace and sustainability. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) CHRISTINA MACFARLANE, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR AND CORRESPONDENT (voiceover):  The fjords of Western Norway provide a breathtaking backdrop to a unique international organization rooted in Nordic culture.

utterances.speaker: JAMES CONNELL, STUDENT, UWC RED CROSS NORDIC
utterances.sentences: UWC Red Cross Nordic is an international school teaching students aged from 16 to 19 located on thewest coast of Norway.

utterances.speaker: MACFARLANE
utterances.sentences: With 200 students from 90 countries, UWC Red Cross Nordic offers a unique learning environment.

utterances.speaker: MAHDULIKA SINGH, TEACHER, UWC RED CROSS NORDIC
utterances.sentences: The college has environment as one of our base pillars, so we focus a lot on environmentand impact on environment. So this sort of comes in everything we do.

utterances.speaker: MACFARLANE
utterances.sentences: The school is supported by the Red Cross and encourages students to take action to protect people and places in need. At the centerof their education model is a project-based learning, or PBL.

utterances.speaker: SINGH
utterances.sentences: Project-based learning basically implies that they are the ones who are part of the planning and they do the project and then they evaluate andlook into how things work.

utterances.speaker: MACFARLANE
utterances.sentences: A recent study found that Norway contributes an estimated 15,000 tons of plastic waste into the environment annually, and with almost29,000 kilometers of coastline, plastic pollution poses a threat to marine ecosystems around the country.

utterances.speaker: SINGH
utterances.sentences: Norway has one of the longest coasts in the world and that is why it makes it so complicated, right?

utterances.speaker: MACFARLANE
utterances.sentences: During the coastal cleanup PBL, the students are leaving their dorms and embracing Norwegian coastal culture.

utterances.speaker: DALMAS OREJE NGANYI, STUDENT, UWC RED CROSS NORDIC
utterances.sentences: We`re living in a boat for five days. It`s just a joy being when you wake up and there`s a littlebit of waves you wake up to, you know, some rowing and it`s totally magnificent.

utterances.speaker: NORKIS VALERO MENDEZ, STUDENT, UWC RED CROSS NORDIC
utterances.sentences: It has been really great. I haven`t been in a boat before. Sometimes it moves and it`s a bitscary but it`s really, really cool.

utterances.speaker: MACFARLANE
utterances.sentences: The project has been running for the past four years. During this time students have removed several tons of plastic from coastalislands, significantly impacting both the environment and the participants.

utterances.speaker: CONNELL
utterances.sentences: Within the space of about six hours we collected around 300 kilograms of plastic and it was -- it was totally surprising.

utterances.speaker: ANA POL MAYORAL, STUDENT, UWC RED CROSS NORDIC
utterances.sentences: It`s been quite bittersweet. So just opening up and seeing like layers and layers andlayers of plastic where you take out one and there there`s even more and more.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Crazy.

utterances.speaker: VALERO MENDEZ
utterances.sentences: I still really want to make something that thanks to this experience will allow me to inspire other people and to tell them that thisis going on. Thanks to the fact that I saw it with my own eyes.

utterances.speaker: SINGH
utterances.sentences: It doesn`t have to be changing the whole world but if they can make an impact in their own little way in the spaces they are in that littlesort of drop in the ocean probably many drops will make a big difference. (END VIDEOTAPE)
